newsitem.title: USA: Holbrooke expected to be new U.S. Cyprus envoy.
newsitem.headline: Holbrooke expected to be new U.S. Cyprus envoy.

text.p: The Clinton administration is expected to announce the appointment of Richard Holbrooke, who negotiated a Bosnia peace agreement, as new presidential emissary to Cyprus, U.S. officials said on Wednesday.
The officials, who asked not to be identified, said an announcement was expected later in the day.
Holbrooke would replace Richard Beattie, who was named last month by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright as her adviser on incorporating three foreign affairs agencies into the State Department.
Holbrooke, noted for his tough bargaining style, made his name by negotiating the 1995 Dayton peace agreement which ended a 43-month civil war in Bosnia.
In February last year he resigned as assistant secretary of state and took a job with Credit Suisse First Boston bank in New York, which he still holds.

Shortly before that he had been due to make a push to resolve the long-standing Cyprus dispute but abandoned the attempt after a fresh outbreak of tension between Greece and Turkey over Aegean issues.
Albright, who took office in January, has said several times that Cyprus will be one of her priorities.

Officials said Holbrooke was expected to bring a new vigour to tackling the Cyprus problem. "I think that with Holbrooke there will be serious attention and movement. Look at what he did in Bosnia," one said.

"It's an important problem and this is obviously someone who has quite a track record in solving difficult negotiating problems," another official said. "President Clinton has said for some time he wanted to adress the Cyprus issue and he has great confidence in ambassador Holbrooke."
Leaders of the Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities are to hold U.N.-sponsored talks next month on how to reunite the island, divided after a Turkish invasion in 1974.

President Glafcos Clerides, as Greek Cypriot leader, and Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash, who heads a Turkish Cypriot breakaway state in northern Cyprus recognised only by Ankara, are to meet in New York in their first face-to-face encounter for nearly three years.
Some 30,000 Turkish troops are stationed in northern Cyprus, occupied in 1974 in response to a brief Greek Cypriot coup engineered by the military then ruling Greece.
